Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: A trait-based approach for understanding the relationship between microbial community assembly and metabolic function
Award.AbstractNarration:
Bacteria compose the majority of the planetary biodiversity and inhabit almost every corner of our planet. Bacteria are the engines that drive Earth's biogeochemical cycles and help to sustain life. Scientific papers are published daily on what types of bacteria live in every imaginable ecosystem. Scientists have found patterns of bacteria community composition in relation to environmental (e.g. temperature, pH, etc.) or host (e.g. disease history, cancer state, etc.) characteristics, but the underlying reasons for the observed patterns remain unclear. Connecting these patterns to a general conceptual framework of how microbes interact with each other and their environment will help scientists to better manage microbes in systems that directly affect people such as human pathogens and wastewater treatment plants. This research will be a step towards addressing this gap in knowledge by adapting frameworks developed in plant systems based on functional characteristics (traits) to microbial ecology, allowing examination of connections between lake bacterial diversity and ecosystems processes using a mechanistic approach. A computational workflow of this project's analysis will be publicly available and used to create open access online educational tools to aid in teaching computational analyses, scientific reproducibility, and programming literacy. Finally, this workflow will be put together to teach a half day workshop at the Ecological Society of America conference.

This research examines how the relationship between bacterial diversity and secondary productivity is constrained by the traits that determine community assembly. Through a comparative genomic analysis of published and newly reconstructed bacterial genomes from environmental genomic data, this project will identify DNA-inferred (a) response traits that control the differences in bacterial community composition and (b) effect traits that determine the presence or absence of a diversity-productivity relationship. The identified genes and inferred traits will help expand current understanding of how bacterial community assembly and processes affect ecosystem function. This understanding will improve linkages between microbial community and ecosystem ecology principles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A core question in biology is do shifts in community composition also result in predictable changes in biological function? This question is especially interesting in the context of microbial communities which occupy every ecosystem on the planet and typically display considerable functional redundancy. One way to gain a deeper understanding of the mechanisms that underlie microbial community assembly and function is to evaluate microbial genome traits.

Here, we connected compositional changes and its impacts on bacterial function with the evolutionary traits of freshwater bacterial communities. We focused on bacteria living within two freshwater microhabitats: particles and the free water. Money from this NSF DDIG grant allowed us to sequence DNA samples collected from Muskegon Lake, a freshwater lake connected to Lake Michigan in the Great Lakes Region. We trained four undergraduate researchers to aid in field collection of the samples and in DNA extraction of samples the laboratory. After sequencing, we developed a bioinformatic workflow to assemble and ?bin? environmental sequences into bacterial population-level genomes (also called metagenome assembled genomes or MAGs). 

Initial findings show that bacterial taxa that inhabit particles or the free water also have significantly different genomic characteristics, with those that generalize between the two microhabitats displaying traits in between the two. For example, bacteria that specialize in freshwater particles have genomes that are twice the size of those that specialize in living freely in the water, with generalists having genome sizes in the middle. We found that this dramatic difference in genome size was due in part to particle specialists having more non-coding DNA, unique genes, and regulatory factors than those of free-living bacterial specialists. These results show that the ecology of freshwater bacteria can be inferred even from broad genomic traits, aiding in the predictability of microbial communities and their function in the future. This project was presented at the 2019 Society of Molecular Biology and Evolution conference and has a manuscript in advanced phases of preparation to be submitted for publication.

The expertise gained from this project helped Dr. Schmidt to teach and contribute to publicly-available materials of a 2-week bioinformatic workshop in 2017 and 2019 that can be accessed at the following link: https://angus.readthedocs.io/en/2019/. During the period of this grant, Dr. Schmidt also taught three Software Carpentry workshops at different universities to introduce students and researchers to coding in unix and R, version control, and reproducible computational workflows. She also presented to the public on how to use helpful functions for data wrangling in R.
